sen.j: 朝原内親王（あさはら（あしたはら）ないしんのう、宝亀10年（779年） - 弘仁8年4月25日（817年5月18日））は、桓武天皇と酒人内親王の皇女。
sen.e: Imperial Princess Asahara (Ashitahara) (779 - May 18, 817) was the Princess of Emperor Kanmu and Imperial Princess Sakahito.
Imperial Princess Asahara (Ashitahara) (779 - May 18, 817) was the Princess of Emperor Kanmu and Imperial Princess Sakahito.
Imperial Princess Asahara, also pronounced Ashitahara (779 - May 18, 817) was the Princess of Emperor Kanmu and Imperial Princess Sakahito.
She became a Itsukinomiya (unmarried princess sho, in former times, was sent by the emperor to serve at Ise Shrine), then she became Emperor Heizei's Empress.

sen.j: 延暦元年（782年）8月1日、4歳で斎王にト定された。
sen.e: She was decided to become Itsukinomiko by the fortune-teller on August 1, 782, when she was four years old.

It was decided for her to become Itsukinomiko (an unmarried princess who, was sent by the emperor to serve at Ise Shrine) based upon the advice of a fortune-teller on August 1, 782, when she was just four years old.

sen.e: It was decided for her to become Itsukinomiko (an unmarried princess who, was sent by the emperor to serve at Ise Shrine) based upon the advice of a fortune-teller on September 16, 782, when she was just four years old.

sen.j: 延暦4年（785年）8月24日、斎王派遣の儀式を旧都の平城京でおこない、朝原内親王の伊勢下向を見送るため、桓武天皇は長岡京から旧都の平城京へ行幸した。
sen.e: On August 24, 785, the ceremony to send Itsukinomiko was held in the former city, Heijokyo (the ancient capital of Heijo), Emperor Kanmu went from Nagaokakyo (the ancient capital of Nagaoka) to the former city, Heijokyo to see off Imperial Princess Asahara (Ashitahara) to go to Ise.

On August 24, 785, a ceremony to send off Itsukinomiko was held in the former city, Heijokyo (the ancient capital of Heijo), Emperor Kanmu went from Nagaokakyo (the ancient capital of Nagaoka) to the former city, Heijokyo to see Imperial Princess Asahara (Ashitahara) off on her trip to Ise.

On October 5, 785, a ceremony to send off Itsukinomiko was held in the former city, Heijokyo (the ancient capital of Heijo), Emperor Kanmu went from Nagaokakyo (the ancient capital of Nagaoka) to the former city, Heijokyo to see Imperial Princess Asahara off on her trip to Ise.

sen.j: 9月7日、朝原内親王は父の桓武天皇と大勢の臣下達に見送られ、伊勢の斎宮へと下向していった。
sen.e: On September 7, Imperial Princess Asahara (Ashitahara) went to Itsukinomiya of Ise after having Emperor Kanmu and many other aides to see her off.

She arrived at Itsukinomiya on 15 September.

sen.j: 延暦15年（796年）2月15日、斎宮で斎王解任のための奉幣使が立てられ、3月15日には平安京から朝原内親王の帰京を求める奉迎使左少弁兼左兵衛佐橘朝臣入居が派遣された。
sen.e: On February 15, 796, an Imperial messenger to a Shinto shrine to let Saio/Itsukinomiko off her position in Itsukinomiya, there was another Imperial messenger, Sashoben and Sahyoenosuke, TACHIBANA no Asomi Irii was sent to have Saio/Itsukinomiko back on 15 March.

On February 15, 796, an Imperial messenger arrived at the Shinto shrine in Itsukinomiya to give Saio/Itsukinomiko some time off from her position, there were other Imperial messengers, Sashoben and Sahyoenosuke, TACHIBANA no Asomi Irii, who were sent from Heijokyo (the ancient capital of Heijo), to have Saio/Itsukinomiko return to Kyoto on 15 March.
sen.cmt: revised for clarity, but it's not clear how the messengers relayed their messages to Saio/Itsukinomiko. Where were the messages handed over and who received the messages? Where did Saio/Itsukinomiko go and where did she come back from?[From Translator]I could not tell from the original Japanese sentence where the first messenger was sent from and sent to, but Japanese word, 奉幣使 has a meaning of messenger who is sent to the Shrine, so I think the first messenger was sent to Shinto shrine of Itsukinomiya but could not tell where he or she was sent from.
sen.e: On April 1, 796, an Imperial messenger arrived at the Shinto shrine in Itsukinomiya to give Itsukinomiko some time off from her position, there were other Imperial messengers, Sashoben and Sahyoenosuke, TACHIBANA no Asomi Irii, who were sent from Heijokyo (the ancient capital of Heijo), to have Itsukinomiko return to Kyoto on April 30.

sen.j: これにより、朝原内親王は平安京に帰京する。
sen.e: Due to this Imperial Princess Asahara/Ashitahara went back to Heiankyo (the ancient capital of Heian)

sen.e: After some Imperial messengers were sent to Itsukinomiya, Imperial Princess Asahara returned to Heiankyo (the ancient capital of Heian).

sen.j: 帰京後の7月9日、桓武天皇の皇女達の中では最初に三品に叙せられた。
sen.e: After she went back to Heiankyo on July 9, she was appointed as Sanbon (the third rank of Imperial Prince), she was one of the first to receive Sanbon within Emperor Kanmu's Princess.

sen.j: 12月14日には桓武天皇が京中巡幸の途中、朝原内親王邸を訪ねて、従五位以上の人々に物を賜った。
sen.e: On December 14, Emperor Kanmu came to visit Imperial Princess Asahara/Ashitahara's Palace on his way to visit Kyoto, she gave gifts to people who were more than Jugoinojo. (Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade)

sen.j: のち異母兄の安殿親王（後の平城天皇）に入内。

sen.e: On September 19, 798 Imperial Princess Asahara/Ashitahara was given two hundred fifty cho (about 610 ares) of rice field in Echigo Province.

sen.e: After Emperor Kanmu died on March 17, Emperor Heizei succeeded to the throne and she became the Empress.

sen.j: 嵯峨天皇が遣わした六人の僧達が、朝原内親王の病気平癒を祈ったが、4月25日、39歳で亡くなった。
sen.e: Although Emperor Saga sent six monks to pray for Imperial Princess Asahara/Ashitahara's illness, she died on April 25, when she was thirty nine years old.

sen.j: 朝原内親王は、自分の諸領地を東大寺に施入させる事と、春には父の桓武天皇のために大般若経を、秋には母の酒人内親王のために金剛般若経を唱えさせる事を遺言した。
sen.e: She left her will to donate all her private land to Todai-ji Temple, to organize Daihannyakyo (the Great Sutra of the Perfection of Transcendent Wisdon) for the sake of her father, Emperor Kanmu in spring, and to chant Kongohannyakyo (the Diamond Sutra) for her mother, Imperial Princess Sakahito in Autumn.
